update.description:
SDFormat has a convention of using -1 to represent positive infinity. If users of the DOM API are not careful and cognizant of this convention, it can result in confusing bugs that are hard to track down. My dartsim plugin was exhibiting subtle non-physical behavior after loading structures from SDF, because it had effort and velocity limits of \+1 \(minimum\) and -1 \(maximum\).

This PR is a suggested tweak to the API behavior so that the API returns positive infinity instead of -1 to represent boundlessly positive values. Hopefully this might save other SDF users from long, confusing debugging sessions.

However, this does deviate from the exact convention of the SDF document specification, so I’d understand if this PR is declined.
update.title: [Suggestion] Return positive infinity instead of -1 for boundless positive values

content.raw:
> If we want to officially support users putting “+/-inf” into their SDF documents and add it to the specification, then I could write some tests to make sure we’re parsing “inf” correctly and then add it to the documentation.

This sounds good to me. This makes more sense than interpreting negative numbers as inf. Are you able to add these tests?
content.html:
If we want to officially support users putting “+/-inf” into their SDF documents and add it to the specification, then I could write some tests to make sure we’re parsing “inf” correctly and then add it to the documentation.

This sounds good to me. This makes more sense than interpreting negative numbers as inf. Are you able to add these tests?

pull_request.title: [Suggestion] Return positive infinity instead of -1 for boundless positive values

pullrequest.title: [Suggestion] Return positive infinity instead of -1 for boundless positive values

content.raw:
Do you mean updating the SDF XML specification?

The changes in this PR only affect the output of SDF’s DOM API. I didn’t want to alter the XML specification, because that could be harmful to backwards compatibility.

I believe it's already possible for users to pass "inf" into an SDF file, and it will get lexicographically parsed to a floating point infinity, but I don't know if that's something we officially support, or if it's just a happy coincidence from using `std::stod`.

If we want to officially support users putting “\+/-inf” into their SDF documents and add it to the specification, then I could write some tests to make sure we’re parsing “inf” correctly and then add it to the documentation.
content.html:
Do you mean updating the SDF XML specification?

The changes in this PR only affect the output of SDF’s DOM API. I didn’t want to alter the XML specification, because that could be harmful to backwards compatibility.

I believe it's already possible for users to pass "inf" into an SDF file, and it will get lexicographically parsed to a floating point infinity, but I don't know if that's something we officially support, or if it's just a happy coincidence from using std::stod.

If we want to officially support users putting “+/-inf” into their SDF documents and add it to the specification, then I could write some tests to make sure we’re parsing “inf” correctly and then add it to the documentation.
